raw_comment: I notice that on average, women are more likely to contact their parents multiple times a week in every aspect of communication. I also notice that most young people prefer texting and calling to visiting their parents. Maybe this is because they live far away from them and it is just easier to text or call. I wonder why women are more likely to reach out to their parents than men. Is this just a recent thing or has it been like this for a long time? This relates to me because I feel like I text and call my parents a lot more than my brother does, so the graph is pretty accurate for me. A headline for this graph could be "Does gender impact communication?"
ace_sentences: On average, women are more likely than men to contact their parents multiple times a week.
This is true for every aspect of communication.
Most young people prefer texting and calling to visiting their parents.
Many young people live far away from their parents.
If a young person lives far away from the parents, then it is easier for the young person to text the parents or to call the parents.
Women are more likely than men to reach out to their parents.
I wonder why women are more likely than men to reach out to their parents.
I wonder whether this difference is recent.
I wonder whether this difference has existed for a long time.
I text my parents a lot.
I call my parents a lot.
My brother texts our parents less than I text our parents.
My brother calls our parents less than I call our parents.
The graph is accurate for me.
The headline is: Does gender impact communication?
